nodes.bodyText:
I've used dependencies from  information-view: https://github.com/odpi/egeria/blob/master/open-metadata-implementation/access-services/information-view/information-view-server/pom.xml
It has both JUnit 4 and JUnit 5 dependencies:
   <dependency>
        <groupId>org.junit.jupiter</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit-jupiter-api</artifactId>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

    <dependency>
        <groupId>junit</groupId>
        <artifactId>junit</artifactId>
        <scope>test</scope>
    </dependency>

I've used JUnit 5 which is junit-jupiter-api.
Please confirm if JUnit 4 is the test framework used. Some test code changes are required to move to JUnit 4 from 5.
Actually, JUnit 4 implementations (setups and test annotations, asserts) are used in the code of the information-view plugin. Same as for other modules having dependency on junit-jupiter-api.

nodes.bodyText:
For unit test, This is junit 5. I would err towards this newer version if possible, it's already used in some modules, though many still use junit 4.
We also use mockito .
If you have preferred testing frameworks we're open to ideas too - whilst also wanting to retain some consistency. I tried spock at one point, which was interesting.

nodes.bodyText: Need to work on these messages - should be explaining what the service does and what to look out for in the start up
There are handlers in the common services that do this - better to use them rather than creating own implementation.
Need to pass the server userId or end user's id - not a fixed value.
Extend the base class rather than implement the interface
class is removed till event implementation
Asset or Database handler?
fixed
Need to handle runtime exceptions and get them to the audit log - no exception class should leave the server because it has a stack trace in it.

Typically APIs support 3 checked exceptions - InvalidParameterException, UserNotAuthorizedException and PropertyServerException.  This enables the caller to work out if it is a coding error, set up error (ie user not set up correctly) or a deeper issue in the metadata ecosystem.
Should be using the platform services - not having your own map since your service will not be listed in the platform API query of the server's active services

nodes.bodyText: Need a specialized response object for each type of response - otherwise can not see what is returned.
Write audit log record of type "EVENT"
class removed in abfeb80
Not interested in new entities? Or reclassified entities that could indicate that an asset has moved into a supported zone?
class removed in abfeb80
Should not be wrapping checked exceptions in a runtime exception - need to let them flow to client.

Use repository handler because it has error handling in it.
If the GUID is not valid, the result is EntityNotKnownException.  This is being mapped to a get entity exception and the null reponse is being mapped to an entity not found error code - I think this might be confusing to debug.

What if there are 4000 databases to return - need paging.
This is a general comment - all of the APIs that retrieve a list need paging parameters.
In addition the userId need to be passed so it can be used on the call to the repository connector - otherwise the repositroy connector will throw an exception if the user is not correct when security is turned on.

Need to validate that GUID is not null - in fact this is a general comment that parameters coming from the API need to be policed both client side and server side.  The server side parameter validation is typically done in the handler layer.

This is an expensive way to get the method name - typically we set up a static final string in the REST services layer and pass it down - it means that the method name in externalised messages and exceptions is a method name that is meaningful to the consumer.
For logic/unexpected errors the stack trace is logged to the audit log in an EXCEPTION message.
For checked exceptions, the error handling values should have enough information to debug the problem without the stack trace.
fixed

Debug logging should not be used for error handling.  This logging will be turned off in a production environment.
We also avoid using variable names of a single letter because it makes it harder for someone else to read.

Need to filter returned assets to removed those not in the supported zones.
(This is done for you if you use the relationalDatabaseHandler - or if you don't like that, the more primitive asset handler)

I think Mandy mentioned this, but the intent would be to have more generalization with the intent (albeit difficult on a sample of 1) to support different tools in the same class - so I wouldn't expect the omas to be cognos specific

nodes.bodyText:
We will presumably get INFO messages in the build - just need to ensure these are kept manageable and don't log any text with ERROR or WARNING to aid in parsing the results.
Further -- note that for the chassis by default all output should be through the audit logging framework - we have logging disabled by default

nodes.bodyText: This audit log entry is an INFO not DEBUG - this means it should not be putput one each requests.  Either use SLF4J or turn the Category to be DEBUG
These message descriptions will not pass the audit log unit test.  It is ok for an initial drop but needs to be improved - look at unit test for the Audit log and exceptions in Asset Owner OMAS

nodes.bodyText: This error handling is merging errors due to bad parameters, security errors and errors in the repositorys into a single exception.  This makes it hard for the client to recover.  See https://egeria.odpi.org/open-metadata-publication/website/diagnostic-guide/
I can not see 1) where the security verifier is called to check the user has access to the asset - or the supportedZones are checked.
remove cognos
wrong class. -not cognos?
